description: Inherited from Middle English shaven, schaven, from Old English sƒãafan (‚Äúto shave, scrape, shred, polish‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *skaban, from Proto-Germanic *skabanƒÖ (‚Äúto scratch‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *skab ∞- (‚Äúto cut, split, form, carve‚Äù).

Cognate with West Frisian skave, Dutch schaven (‚Äúto shave, plane‚Äù), Low German schaven (‚Äúto scrape, scratch, shave‚Äù), German schaben (‚Äúto scrape, shave‚Äù), Danish skave, Norwegian Nynorsk skava, Swedish skava (‚Äúto scrape, chafe‚Äù), Icelandic skafa, Gothic êçÉêå∫êå∞êå±êå∞êåΩ (skaban, ‚Äúto shear, shave‚Äù).

verbs.description: shave (third-person singular simple present shaves, present participle shaving, simple past shaved or (obsolete) shove, past participle shaved or shaven)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (the head, skin etc.) bald or (the hair) shorter by using a tool such as a razor or electric clippers to cut the hair close to the skin.
(transitive) To cut anything in this fashion.
examples: The labourer with the bending scythe is seen / Shaving the surface of the waving green.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To remove hair from one's face by this means.
examples: I had little time to shave this morning.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut finely, as with slices of meat.
To skim along or near the surface of; to pass close to, or touch lightly, in passing.
To reduce in size or weight.
(archaic, transitive) To be hard and severe in a bargain with; to practice extortion on; to cheat.
(US, slang, dated, transitive) To buy (a note) at a discount greater than the legal rate of interest, or to deduct in discounting it more than the legal rate allows.

description: From Middle English shave, from Old English sceafa, from Proto-Germanic *skab√¥.

examples: I instructed the barber to give me a shave.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, dated) An exorbitant discount on a note.
(US, slang, dated) A premium paid for an extension of the time of delivery or payment, or for the right to vary a stock contract in any particular.
A hand tool consisting of a sharp blade with a handle at each end; a spokeshave.
(informal) A narrow miss or escape; a close shave.
examples: " [‚Ä¶]  I had an awful shave getting into the harbour," remarked Archie.
